moves.2. d4: fighting for control of the center
moves.2... c6 3. c4 e6 4. Nbd2 Nf6 5. e3 c5: This position looks strange, but black reckons that the d-2 knight is not well placed to battle for central control.
moves.7. Bb2 cxd4: clearing a path for it's dark squared bishop
moves.10... Bd7 11. O-O: The opening has been a success for White. He has good central control, and prospects of a gradual queenside advance. There is no direct plan for Black, so it starts to drift for a few moves, with disastrous consequences. The bishop is already a little clumsy on d7; I suspect a strong human player would have started to devise a plan to liberate the game back on move 10.
moves.11... Nh5: An over-ambitious idea. Few GMs felt that ...Nh5 was anything other than a bad move.
moves.14... Ng6 15. Ne5: central knight hoping for a trade
moves.15... Rc8: fighting for control of the c-file
moves.16. Nxd7: trading well placed knight for a back-up role bishop
moves.19... Nge7: White now has an iteresting combinational oppurtunity, 20 Bxh7  Kxh7 21 Ng5 ...... but Kasparov made the correct political decision by keeping things simple, for it would only require the slightest hole in the combination to cost White the game.
moves.20... Ba5: After Kasparov's move the game was far simpler
moves.21. b4: gaining space and attacking the queenside
moves.22. c5: adding more queenside space and going into blacks territory.
moves.23... g6 24. Re2: White is much better, still in a simple position. With his plan of rolling Black up on the queenside, Kasparov at this point must have been pretty confident in winning.
moves.24... Nf5: making a reasonable flight square for his knight on c6
moves.25... h5: gaining kingside space, but opening a hole
moves.26... Nce7: All of blacks pieces are now in the back and are no threat what so ever to Whites king
moves.27. Bd2: The bishop having much more scope on d2 than b2
moves.27... Kg7: protecting h6 a little more thouroughly
moves.29. a5 a6 30. b6: diving deeper into Black's palace and forcing another retreat
moves.30... Bb8: Trapping the a8-rook in a corner. Black might be able to erect some sort of defence based on the control ofc6, but White will place his bishop on a4 and taunt Black with ideas of Ne5 or infiltration on the kingside dark squares- or else a massive kingside onslaught if Black goes into a queenside huddle.
moves.31... Nc6 32. Ba4 Re7 33. Bc3 Ne5: The computer spots a freeing tactic, but it's to no avail.
moves.34. dxe5 Qxa4 35. Nd4 Nxd4 36. Qxd4 Qd7: Black can barely move. The end is near for Deep Blue.
moves.39. Bf6+ Kh7: Blacks position is a total disaster! To add injury to insult, Kasparov can now execute a tactical breakthrough
moves.40. c6 bxc6: Black cannot avoid giving White a passed b-pawn, since 40...Rxc6 41 Rec2  Rxc2 42 Rxc2 leaves black completely helpless.
moves.41. Qc5 Kh6 42. Rb2 Qb7 43. Rb4: Black has no moves apart from shuffling his king. White has all the time in the world to walk in to finish the rout. 1-0
